tool.name: RXLR-EER Motifs (Whisson et al. 2007, heuristic)
tool.description: Find RXLR-EER Effectors of Plant Pathogenic Oomycetes
tool.command: rxlr_whisson_et_al_2007_re.py $fasta_file 8 $tabular_file ##I want the number of threads to be a Galaxy config option...

data.name: tabular_file
data.label: RXLR-EER (Whisson et al. 2007 heuristic model) results

tool.help:
**What it does**
Many effector proteins from Oomycete plant pathogens for manipulating the host have been found to contain a signal peptide followed by a conserved RXLR motif (Arg, any amino acid, Leu, Arg), and then sometimes EER (Glu, Glu, Arg). There are stiking parallels with the malarial host-targeting signal.
This tool looks for the protein motif RXLR-EER using the heuristic regular expression methodolgy described in Whisson et al. (2007), which was an extension of the RXLR clasffier described in Bhattacharjee et al. (2006).
It requires a protein sequence FASTA file as input, and produces a simple tabular file as output with one line per protein, and two columns giving the sequence ID and whether or not it had an RXLR-EER motif (Y or N).
Declaring a protein to have an RXLR-EER motif requires a SignalP 3.0 Hidden Markov Model (HMM) score of at least 0.9, with the Neural Network predicted cleavage site giving a signal peptide length between 10 and 40 amino acids, with the RXLR-EER regular expression after this and starting within 100 amino acids of the signal peptide clevage site.
The RXLR-EER motif is defined with the regular expression R.LR.{,40}[ED][ED][KR] which means RXLR (Arg, any amino acid, Leu, Arg), then a stretch of up to forty amino acids before Glu/Asp, Glu/Asp, Lys/Arg. The EER part of the name is perhaps misleading as it also allows for DDR, EEK, and so on.
Note that Whisson et al. (2007) also describes a second RXLR-EER classifier using a Hidden Markov Model (HMM). See also Win et al. (2007) for related classifier.
